title: Rearrange
text: The first step is to rewrite the function and simplify it so we can apply the power rule: $$\int_{1}^{4} \sqrt{t} \left(1+t\right) \,dt=\int_{1}^{4} t^{\frac{1}{2}} \left(1+t\right) \,dt$$
speech: The first step is to rewrite the function and simplify it so we can apply the power rule:  the integral from 1 to 4 of the square root of t times, parentheses 1 plus t,  times d t is equal to the integral from 1 to 4 of t raised to the 1 half power parentheses 1 plus t,  times d t

title: Rearrange
text: Contribute $$t^{\frac{1}{2}}$$ into the term inside parenthesis to obtain $$\int_{1}^{4} t^{\frac{1}{2}}+t^{\frac{3}{2}} \,dt$$
speech: Contribute  t raised to the 1 half power  into the term inside parenthesis to obtain , the integral from 1 to 4 of, t raised to the 1 half power plus, t raised to the 3 halves power d t

title: Evaluate the integral
text: As the integral is bounded from $$x=1$$ to $$x=4$$, we have $$\frac{2}{3} 4^{\frac{3}{2}}+\frac{2}{5} 4^{\frac{5}{2}}-\frac{2}{3} 1^{\frac{3}{2}}+\frac{2}{5} 1^{\frac{5}{2}}=\frac{256}{15}$$
